coredata.dc:title: Near-edge and photoemission studies of condensed diborane. Evidence for intermolecular interactions in the solid phase
coredata.dc:creator: Ruckman, M.W.
Murray, M.F.
Mowlem, J.K.
Moore, J.F.
Strongin, D.R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Boron K near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) and photoemission spectra for condensed diborane and argon containing five percent B2H6 (matrix isolated case) were obtained. The near-edge spectrum obtained for the condensed diborane differs from that obtained for the matrix isolated case which resembles that reported for the gas phase. The valence band photoemission from condensed B2H6 appears more similar to that published for B4H10 than that for gaseous diborane. From the spectroscopic data, it is concluded that diborane molecules are affected by intermolecular interactions and undergo a change in electronic structure.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 198, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 October 1992 M.W. Ruckman, M.F. Murray Physics Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, USA J.K. Mowlem, J.F. Moore and D.R. Strongin Department of Chemistry, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY 11794, USA Received 26 June 1992 Boron K near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) and photoemission spectra for condensed diborane and argon containing five percent B2H6 (matrix isolated case) were obtained. The near-edge spectrum obtained for the condensed diborane differs from that obtained for the matrix isolated case which resembles that reported for the gas phase. The valence band photoem- ission from condensed B2H6 appears more similar to that published for B4H0 than that for gaseous diborane. From the spectro- scopic data, it is concluded that diborane molecules are affected by intermolecular interactions and undergo a change in electronic structure. The electronic structure of boranes and their de- localized bonding is of great interest to physical chemists [1]. The multi-center bonding found in boranes is analogous to the sort of bonding found in small metal clusters [2] and the newly discovered fullerenes [3]. Much of the experimental work de- signed to investigate the bonding has involved op- tical probes like Raman spectroscopy or nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) [4]. Much less work has been done using techniques like photoemission which can access both valence and core levels and energy absorption spectroscopies like electron en- ergy loss spectroscopy (EELS) and near-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy (NEXAFS). The photoem- ission work has focused on the examination of gas- eous boranes like B2H6 [5,6] or larger boron hy- drides [7]. Photoemission also has been used to study thin borane and carborane layers adsorbed on surfaces [8]. To the best of our knowledge, the pho- toemission and NEXAFS techniques have not been applied to solid diborane. Correspondence to: D.R, Strongin, Department of Chemistry, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY 11794, USA. This letter reports boron K-edge and photoemis- sion results for pure diborane condensed on a graph- ite substrate and matrix-isolated diborane in argon. The pure diborane film was assembled from the gas phase at 78 K and the matrix-isolated phase by co- condensing an Ar/B2H6 mixture at 15 K. The spec- troscopic data presented in this Letter contains fea- tures which suggest that a modification in the mo- lecular electronic structure takes place in the pure diborane condensed from the gas phase at liquid ni- trogen temperature. The modificiations exceed those usually seen in photoemission or NEXAFS spectra when molecular solids are formed from the gas phase [9]. More complex boranes like tetraborane can be readily synthesized by the compression of diborane gas at room temperature. In spite of this, the issue of intermolecular bonding in B2F16 has often been ig- nored or dismissed in earlier work [10,11]. We condensed the diborane from a commercial 5% B2H6 mixture in argon onto an exfoliated highly ori- ented pyrolytic graphite (HOPO) wafer at 7 8 79 K. The diborane films were condensed on graphite sub- strates to minimize their interaction with the sub- strate. A mass spectrometer was used to examine the gas and check its composition. The characteristic 449 0009-2614/92/S 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.Y. All rights reserved. Near-edge and photoemission studies of condensed diborane. Evidence for intermolecular interactions in the solid phase Volume 198, number S CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETtERS 16 October 1992 cracking pattern for diborane was seen and mass peaks for other boranes were not detected. We also monitored the desorption of the diborane from the substrate upon heating and found that the diborane desorbed from the surface between 100 and 115 K. The spectroscopic work was done in an ultra-high vacuum system of conventional design with a base pressure of 5 X 10~ Ton. To condense the dibor- ane, a jet of the diborane/Ar mixture was directed onto the liquid nitrogen cooled substrate. The argon partial pressure was (l 2) x 1 O_5 Ton during de- position and the ionization gauge was turned off to minimize ionization after the pressure was stabi- lized. The diborane film was sufficiently thick after condensation to completely obscure photoemission from the C ls peak but not so thick as to cause charg- ing during photoemission. The matrix-isolated di- borane was condensed onto a silver film from the same B2H6/Ar mixture, but the substrate was cooled to 15 K to ensure the co-condensation of the argon which had a partial pressure of 5 x l0~~ Ton. This film was also thick enough to ensure that the sub- strate has little or no effect on the data. The photoemission data were obtained using a 100 mm hemispherical analyzer and the NEXAFS data were obtained in the total yield mode using an elec- trometer connected to a Faraday cup above the sub- strate. The photoemission data were collected along the sample normal with the photon beam incident at 45 to the sample normal. The photon source for the spectroscopie work was the 750 MeY VUV storage ring at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS). Valence band photoemission spectra for the thick B2H6 film on HOPO and several reference spectra taken from the literature are shown in fig. 1. Spectra are not shown for the matrix-isolated case because the Ar 3p levels obscured the diborane features. We have adjusted the energy scale of fig. 1 to align the reference energy with the Fermi level of the silver support. For comparison of the data for solid B2H6 to that for gas-phase B2H5, it is necessary to compute the binding energy relative to the vacuum level. To compute the binding energy, the work function of the silver support was taken to be 4.2 eV [12] and this has to be added to the apparent binding energy plot- ted in fig. 1 to get the binding energy referenced to the vacuum level. The location of the peaks for the Fig. 1. Normal incidence valence band photoemission from a thick diborane film condensed on graphite at 78 K. The spectrum was obtained at a photon energy of 150 eV using a pass energy of 44 eV. Spectra for gas-phase diborane (ref. [5]) and tetraborane (ref. 113]) are reproduced for comparison with our data for solid B2H6. gaseous and solid phases of B2H6 is marked with ver- tical lines above the graph for the solid and for the gases. Our photoemission data for condensed dibor- ane differs from that published for gaseous diborane by Brundle et al. [5] which is reproduced in fig. I. Ultraviolet photoemission data [5] for gaseous di- borane taken using He 11(40.8 eV) radiation shows six peaks labeled l 6 associated with lb28, 3;, lb3~, 1b211, 2b1~ and 2; energy levels, respectively. Our photoemission spectrum for solid diborane shows six peaks (also labeled 1 6) 9.4, 11.1, 13.0, 14.3, 16.9 and 20.1 eV below the vacuum level. To compare our data with that of gaseous diborane, a shift of 3 eV was applied to the data of Brundle et al. to match his data with the least tightly bound photoemission feature in our data. The rational for applying what appears to be an arbitrary energy shift is that it ac- counts for the screening of the valence holes created by photoemission in the solid state, There is some agreement between the relative positions of peaks 1 C J Co z w I-. z BINDING BNERGY (eV) 450 Volume 198, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 October 1992 through 4 and the five B2H6 energy levels found be- tween 10.0 and 15.0 eV. There is no agreement be- tween peaks 5 and 6 and their gas-phase B2H6 counterpart. The poor agreement between our spectrum for condensed diborane and gas-phase diborane prompted a comparison with the electronic structure of a more complex borane. A photoemission spec- trum for tetraborane (B4H10) from the work of Lloyd et al. [13] also is shown in fig. I. As in the previous case of gas-phase diborane, the data of Lloyd et al. are shifted by 3 eV to align his photoelectron spec- trum with our data. There is better agreement be- tween our data and that reported for tetraborane. For B4H10, Lloyd et al. identifS the first and second peaks or bands (labeled Nos. 1 and 2) as being due to the Sa1, 3b2, 2b1, 4a1 and 2b2 orbitals located 11.5 12.93 eV. The third peak (No. 3) is due to the la2 and 3; orbitais at 14.15 and 14.53 eV and the fourth peak (No. 4) is due to the 2a1 orbital and is 15.85 eV be- low the ionization potential. The fifth and sixth peaks (Nos. Sand 6) are associated with the lb1, lb2 (18.1 and 18.9 eV) and the la1 (23.1 eV) levels, respectively. The electronic structure of the tetraborane mole- cule differs from that of diborane [14] in that the lowest energy level in diborane, the 2a8 level, is formed from B 2s atomic orbitals which are partially mixed with the B 2p states. For tetraborane, the la1 level is nearly all B 2s character and related to the B B bond. The lb1 and lb2 levels are associated with the bridging hydrogen bonds and the terminal hy- drogen bonds and contain contributions from the boron 2s and p states and the hydrogen ls state. At this point, we note that the photoelectron features of condensed B2H6 and B4H10 coincide on a peak-by- peak basis. The apparent similarities between tetra- borane and solid diborane argue for the existence of similarities between the electronic structure of the B4H10 molecule and solid B2H6 condensed from the gas phase. One possible conclusion is that a change in the hybridization of boron and hydrogen states takes place. Fig. 2 shows the NEXAFS data for the boron K- edge for a diborane film on graphite and matrix iso- lated diborane. The NEXAFS result for matrix-iso- lated diborane shown in fig. 2 (upper curve) does not look like that found for condensed diborane but does match that reported for gas-phase diborane [15]. The pre-edge peak marked 1 at 191.5 eV pho- ton energy is very strong, features marked 2 , 3 and 4 are seen at 195, 198 and 202 eV photon energy, respectively. A much weaker peak is seen just above 205 eV photon energy. The data for the matrix-iso- lated case are in good agreement with the only pub- lished B K near-edge data for gas-phase diborane done by electron energy loss spectroscopy. In this study, Zimkina and Vinogradov [15] detected three absorption features between 192 and 200 eV. The lowest feature at 192.5 eV had significantly more os- cillator strength than the features at 194 and 197 eV and was clearly below the ionization threshold. Zimkina and Vinogradov [15] associated the three near-edge features with transitions from the B is level to B 2p states. Self-consistent field (SCF) calcula- tions [16] for diborane indicate there are two un- occupied levels which should be accessed by tran- sitions from the B ls core level. These levels, the lb38 and 4a8, are 1.9 eV apart and are separated from the uppermost occupied level by a gap of 12 eV. The lb38 orbital is a lt*_like orbital associated with the bridg- ing hydrogen bonds between the two boron atoms and the 4a8 is a a*~like orbital also associated with the same B H B bond. We interpret the level at 192.5 eV (peak I ) as a transition from the B ls to e level a 5 4 Co z w I- z 200 210 PHOTON ENERGY (eV( Fig. 2. B~ near-edge spectra ror diborane condensed on graphite and diborane isolated in an argon matrix at 15 K. The spectra are taken in the total yield mode using an electrometer to monitor the sample to ground current. 451 16 October t992 Volume 198, numberS CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS ron nearest neighbors. It should be emphasized that gaseous diborane can be evolved from the pure di- borane when heated to 100 l 10 K which implies that the changes are reversible when the solid is heated and also implies that the intermolecular bonding is weak. This probably rules out the removal of hydro- gen or bond breaking and boron boron bond for- mation required during the formation of tetraborane or pentaborane from diborane. It should also be noted that B4H10 and B5H9 are thermally stable at these and higher temperatures. Like the photoelectron spec- trum shown in fig. 1, however, the NEXAFS spectral similarities between the condensed phase and pen- taborane also suggest some common electronic prop- erties between these materials. The data shown in figs. 1 and 2 argue that di- borane molecules undergo changes in their elec- tronic structure when condensed into the solid state. The fact that diborane is evolved when the solid is evaporated suggests that the bonding is weak and easily broken. If diborane is bound by the mecha- nisms usually associated with the van der Waais in- teraction, the changes are due to a redistribution of charge at boron and hydrogen sites. If the interaction is due to hydrogen bonding, the formation of hy- drogen bonds may cause changes in the hybridiza- tion of boron and the hydrogen atoms. Clearly, fur- ther theoretical study is needed to determine the type of intermolecular interaction in solid diborane and the apparent changes in the electronic structure of the molecule. Differences have been seen in results from other experimental techniques [4] (i.e. the in- frared spectrum) when diborane is condensed and a detailed re-examination of such results could help to identify the exact nature of the changes taking place when diborane is condensed from the vapor phase. To summarize, the photoemission and near-edge experiments show changes in the electronic structure which can be explained by an intermolecular inter- action when diborane is condensed at 78 K. It is not obvious from the data what mechanisms cause the changes seen in the spectra. The spectra suggest that the hybridization between hydrogen and boron changes and there is increased occupation of the un- occupied states associated with the bridging hydro- gen bonds. This work was supported by the US Department and the peak 2.5 eV above it (peak 2 ) as the B is to r~ transition. The features above 195 eV may be related to Rydberg states, a shape resonance or multi- electron excitations during ionization. High-resolu- tion NEXAFS data would greatly aid experimental identification of the features near the ionization threshold. For the pure diborane on graphite (fig. 2, bottom curve), the boron K-edge shows a feature at 190 eV photon energy (peak 1), a prominent peak at 192 eV (peak 2), at least two smaller features at 194 and 195.5 eV (peaks 3 and 4) anda broad peak near 200 eV (peak 5). The data were taken at different angles of incidence to check for evidence of molecular ori- entation on the HOPG substrate. We did this be- cause HOPG can act as a template for the epitaxial growth of crystalline molecular solids. There was lit- tle or no systematic intensity variation with angle which suggests there is no orientational ordering of the molecules. We think the changes in the NEXAFS spectra are due to intermolecular interactions when the dibor- ane is condensed. The nature of the intermolecular interaction and the extent, if any, of the changes in the intramolecular bonds are not clear. These changes could be due to the formation of hydrogen bonds be- tween the diborane molecules or bonding between the bridging hydrogen atoms. The changes could also be due to additional bonding between hydrogen and boron atoms. If the B2H6 molecules combine in the solid state to form a more complex borane, a logical conjecture would be to assume that the new sub- stance resembles tetraborane or pentaborane. We are unaware of NEXAFS data for tetraborane in either the gas or solid phase but NEXAFS data for pen- taborane (B5H9) [17] has recently become avail- able. The B K-edge for pure condensed diborane is remarkably similar to the spectrum obtained for the pentaborane. Examination of the predicted eigen- states for B4H10 indicates the existence of only one dipole allowed transition (B Is to Sa1) and the sharp feature (peak 2) at the B K-edge could be associated with this transition. The unresolved states at 194 195 eV photon energy are likely to be unresolved Rydberg transitions. The peak at 200 eV has many of the characteristics of a shape resonance and we believe it is strong in condensed diborane because of the scattering of the outgoing photoelectron by bo 452 Volume 198, number S CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 October 1992 of Energy, Division of Materials Sciences under Contract No. DE-ACO2-76CH0001 6. The authors thank Fran Loeb for the construction of some of the cryogenic equipment used during this work and H. Wiessmann for preparing the diborane sources. The spectroscopic work was done at the National Syn- chrotron Light Source. One of the authors (MFM) gratefully acknowledges support from the Depart- ment of Energy s Division of University and Indus- try Programs, office of Energy Research, as a Science and Engineering Research Semester (SERS) Pro- gram participant. head.ce:title: Near-edge and photoemission studies of condensed diborane. Evidence for intermolecular interactions in the solid phase

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Boron K near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) and photoemission spectra for condensed diborane and argon containing five percent B2H6 (matrix isolated case) were obtained. The near-edge spectrum obtained for the condensed diborane differs from that obtained for the matrix isolated case which resembles that reported for the gas phase. The valence band photoemission from condensed B2H6 appears more similar to that published for B4H10 than that for gaseous diborane. From the spectroscopic data, it is concluded that diborane molecules are affected by intermolecular interactions and undergo a change in electronic structure.
